docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-8, 15 President Changes Tack On North Korean Plutonium Tacitly acknowledging that North Korea may not be deterred from producing plutonium for nuclear weapons, President Bush is now trying to marshal international support for preventing the country from exporting nuclear material, according to American and foreign officials. A1 Iraq Overseer Criticizes U.N. Jay Garner, the former lieutenant general who has been in Iraq for nearly a month with a mandate to get the country running, criticized the United Nations, blaming it for gasoline shortages that have fueled Iraqi anger at American forces. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: A chain-link fence, two wooden crosses and a plywood heart with angel's wings are all that remain. That and a rectangle of red concrete from the crucible that ended 99 lives and charred many more. The truckload of mementos left by the mourning hordes -- soggy wedding pictures, tangled prayer beads, fading plastic pansies -- has been carted away. The long line of craned-neck drivers on Cowesett Road is gone, too. The sign at a nearby restaurant that urged passers-by to remember the dead now urges them not to forget Mother's Day.

headline.main: Months Past Club Fire, a Struggle to Go On

docs.abstract: Fire that destroyed West Warwick, RI, nightclub on Feb 20 has left unimaginable torrent of misery; 99 people died, and nearly 200 survivors went to hospital, some with burns on 80 percent of their bodies and about half without health insurance; 56 children lost a mother or father or both parents; even those who are physically unscathed bear deep psychic wounds; Missy Minor, hospitalized for 14 days with burns, is back home with with her husband and two children; parents of Pam Gruttadauria, 33, visit her daily at Massachusetts General Hospital, but can barely communicate with her because her injuries are so severe; Janet Van Deusen rages at various parties she holds responsible for burns suffered by her son, John, who is still at Rhode Island Hospital; Melinda Darby mourns her husband, Matthew, while caring for baby born a month after his death; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: CHERIE E. SPITZER considered herself healthy until last February, when she suffered a massive heart attack while on a Caribbean cruise. She lay in the ship's infirmary for two days as the vessel sailed to the nearest major port, in the Dominican Republic. Thirty minutes after the ship docked, she was in a private Lear jet, tended by a British nurse and flying to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where an ambulance whisked her from the airport to a nearby hospital.
docs.abstract: Advice on comprehensive travel insurance that pays for treatment and emergency evacuation when abroad; Medicare and most employer-sponsored health insurance do not cover overseas medical care; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A trip to the diet doc, circa 2013. You prick your finger, draw a little blood and send it, along with a $100 fee, to a consumer genomics lab in California. There, it's passed through a mass spectrometer, where its proteins are analyzed. It is cross-referenced with your DNA profile. A few days later, you get an e-mail message with your recommended diet for the next four weeks. It doesn't look too bad: lots of salmon, spinach, selenium supplements, bread with olive oil. Unsure of just how lucky you ought to feel, you call up a few friends to see what their diets look like. There are plenty of quirks. A Greek co-worker is getting clams, crab, liver and tofu -- a bounty of B vitamins to raise her coenzyme levels. A friend in Chicago, a second-generation Zambian, has been prescribed popcorn, kale, peaches in their own juice and club soda. (This looks a lot like the hypertension-reducing ''Dash'' diet, which doesn't work for everyone but apparently works for him.) He is allowed some chicken, prepared in a saltless marinade, hold the open flame -- and he gets extra vitamin D because there's not enough sunshine for him at his latitude. (His brother's diet, interestingly enough, is a fair bit different.) Your boss, who seems to have won some sort of genetic lottery, gets to eat plenty of peanut butter, red meat and boutique cheeses. Nobody is eating exactly what you are. Your diet is uniquely tailored. It is determined by the specific demands of your genetic signature, and it perfectly balances your micronutrient and macronutrient needs. Sick days have become a foggy memory. (Foggy memory itself is now treated with extracts of ginkgo biloba and a cocktail of omega-3 fatty acids.)

headline.main: What Your Genes Want You to Eat

docs.abstract: Article by Bruce Grierson describes study of nutritional genomics; premise is that influence of diet on health depends on individual's genetic makeup; this would seem to be proved by ill fit between certain cultures and certain diets; but many people have ancestors from different continents, so data are rarely clean-cut; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's Office of Genomics and Disease Prevention warns against genetic testing, but handful of companies are already offering genomics profiles and nutritional supplements to early adopters looking for edge; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC optimism has been a bad bet for more than two years now, but it has not suffered from any shortage of takers. Starting in early 2001, Federal Reserve officials and most Wall Street economists began predicting a quick return to healthy growth, only to repeat the forecast a few months later after they were proved wrong. The Bush administration, which took office offering a presciently sober view, quickly turned to cheerleading reminiscent of the Clinton administration's final months.

headline.main: A Noted Few Make a Case For Optimism (This Time)

docs.abstract: David Leonhardt column on economists who accurately predicted 2001 recession and are now forecasting economic recovery; details views of James W Paulsen; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans are more concerned about paying for health care than they are about paying their mortgage or rent, losing money in the stock market or even having job security, a recent survey shows. Asked how worried they were about a variety of issues, 36 percent of 1,211 adults questioned last month said they were ''very worried'' that their cost for health care services or health insurance would increase. Close behind on the scale was consumer prices: 35 percent said they were very worried that their income would not keep pace with future increases.

headline.main: Health Care Atop the Worry List

docs.abstract: Kaiser Family Foundation survey finds cost of health care or health insurance is top worry for 36 percent of American adults surveyed (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S a small room with bad lighting and scuffed furniture. On a recent Saturday morning, as a cold rain splattered the window and corridor signs announced Alcoholics Anonymous meetings and candy machine hours, the shabbiness of the place was palpable. But for Angel Sanchez, who just got out of jail, a room at the Hartford Y.M.C.A. is a sanctuary he can afford. Hearing the place is scheduled to close left him with a worry as raw as the weather. '''I heard about that and I don't know what I'm going to do,'' he said. '''The only other place for me is the shelter.''
docs.abstract: Article on plans by YMCA in Hartford, Conn, to shut its residential complex and adverse impact it is likely to have on its residents; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BRIGITTE EMILIA CROCOS had been a little concerned. Before she arrived in the United States last week to embark on her adventure as an au pair, Ms. Crocos, a 22-year-old German college student, called her host family in Bridgewater, N.J., to find out whether Germans are still welcome in the United States. She had also look up information about SARS on the Web site of the World Health Organization. ''My house mom said Germans are still treated well here,'' said Ms. Crocos, who is in the United States for the first time. '' And SARS? ''There are not so many cases in America, and nobody has died from it,'' she said.

headline.main: Coming to America, Au Pairs Aren't Daunted

docs.abstract: Article on steady stream of au pairs arriving in New York metropolitan area from around world despite war in Iraq, economic woes and fear of SARS; while full-time nanny can cost up to $500 a week, host family pays au pair $140 a week, amount set by State Department, and onetime fee of about $5,000 to cover transporation from home country, health insurance and orientation; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With six-figure salaries and prestigious educations, the executives featured in Jonathan Mahler's article (April 13) reaped the benefits of prosperous times while the average American worker saw only modest economic gains. These men have savings, assets and spouses to provide an economic safety net that most unemployed of more modest means would greatly envy. They are also fortunate that they and their families are in good health. A more realistic depiction of the perils of the unemployed and uninsured was the one portrayed in a Lives column in February about a woman with cancer and her unemployed husband. Bankrupted by insurance costs, they were on the verge of homelessness and reduced to begging for food money. If politicians wonder what constitutes real fear and terror for most Americans, this story should serve as a brutal economic primer. A.M. Masisak Trumbull, Conn.
docs.abstract: A M Masiak letter comments on Jonathan Mahler's April 13 article on men who once had high-paying jobs and are now out of work

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Stress Is Up. So Why Are Mental Health Benefits Down?'' (Money & Medicine, April 20) described the increased costs to business from depression- and stress-related disability as a result of reductions in mental health insurance benefits: There is no doubt that the costs of losing an employee to disability are high. One large Baltimore company estimates it costs $60,000 to replace a midlevel worker: $5,000 to terminate an employee, $5,000 to hire a replacement, and $50,000 for new training. Even after that, it estimates that the new employee is only 80 percent productive during the first two years of employment.

headline.main: Reduced Benefits For Mental Health Care

docs.abstract: Dr Alan M Langlieb letter on Apr 20 article details costs to company of losing employee to depression- and stress-related disability as result of cuts in mental health insurance benefits; drawing
